title-group.article-title: Hygrothermally induced buckling analysis of elastically supported laminated composite plates with random system properties

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Applied Mechanics, SVNIT, Surat, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, SVNIT, Surat, India
3Department of Aerospace Engineering, IIT, Kharapur, India

author-notes.corresp: Achchhe Lal, Department of Mechanical Engineering, SVNIT, Surat-395007, India Email: achchhelal@med.svnit.ac.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The article presents hygrothermally induced buckling of geometrically linear laminated composite plates resting on two parameters Pasternak elastic foundation subjected to moisture and temperature-independent and -dependent material properties with random system properties. System properties such as elastic moduli, shear moduli of the constituent materials, hygroscopic contraction coefficients, thermal expansion coefficients, and foundation stiffness parameters are modeled as independent basic random variables. A computationally efficient C 0 finite element method combined with Taylor series based mean-centered first-order perturbation technique via higher order shear deformation plate theory is used to solve the random eigenvalue problem. Typical numerical results for dimensional mean and coefficient of variance of hygrothermally induced buckling load of laminated composite plate subjected to uniform hygrothermal loadings are examined with uniform moisture concentration and temperature rise, plate thickness and aspect ratios, total number of plies, fiber orientations, elastic foundations, and different boundary conditions with random system properties. The numerical results obtained by the present solution approach are validated with those available in the literatures and independent Monte Carlo simulation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Laminated composite plates play an important and vital role in exceptional performance extreme engineering structures as aeronautical and aerospace engineering for construction, manufacturing of aircrafts structural components, automobile engineering as body panels and frames, bumpers, leaf springs, civil engineering as bridges, columns; fiber-reinforced plastics re-bars and others as wind turbine blades, pens, etc. In construction of the above-mentioned structures/components there is operational and functional requirement of inherent characteristic ability to tailor structural properties through appropriate lamination schemes for achieving high strength and stiffness-to-weight ratio with high structural efficiency and durability according to use. Now-a-days advanced reinforced composites are being widely used in modern aerospace transportation systems and for high performance applications in other areas also. The plates made up of these composites are often subjected to destabilizing mechanical loading in hygrothermal environment. Due to boundary constraints in the composite plates by varying moisture and temperature environments besides other factors induce significant strains, which may have adverse effect on the stiffness and strength of the composite and consequently may have affected the stability and safety of the structures, thereby needs ensuing hygrothermal buckling behavior. Keeping in mind the strength and stiffness, a careful evaluation of the environmental exposure is required to find the nature and extent of their deleterious effect upon the performance of structures in sensitive applications. Therefore, it is of utmost importance to understand the hygrothermally induced buckling load behavior of these structural systems in order to estimate the reserve strength. Apart from these, the plate resting on elastic foundation is one of the important areas of research. It is widely used in operational activity of large transport aircraft on runways, launching sites of missiles and aircraft, foundation of deep wells, storage tank of oil refineries, slab of buildings, mat and raft foundations, bridges, etc. In this direction, the two parameters Pasternak foundation model consisting of spring layers and shear layers has proved to be most effective and very useful mainly for design perspective. The exact modeling of elastic foundation at which structures are rested is one of the important areas of research. It is not possible to make the elastic foundation in exact sense. And it is not possible to determine the material properties of the supporting elastic media (foundation) as these are totally dependent on material properties of supporting media and modeling. Therefore, reliability of the design, accurate prediction of overall system behavior of the structures made of composite plates and the foundation at which plate is rested are need.

The common deterministic analysis is based on the assumptions of the system properties is completely determinacy i. e., system uncertainties are neglected and only the mean response is analyzed which unaccounted the dispersion caused by the inherent randomness in the system parameters. Due to the large number of parameters are associate with manufacturing fabrication and processing of composite components as compared to conventional materials, the complete control at each stage of any design parameters is very difficult. Lack of control at each stage of manufacturing/processing condition leads to dispersion in the system properties. This is especially true for laminated composites. The uncertainty at the microlevel is finally reflected at macro level in the form of lamina material properties such as longitudinal and transverse modulii, shear modulii, and Poisson’s ratio. The presence of these uncertainties significantly affects the fundamental structural characteristics such as stability (buckling); consequently they must affect the final design. Since such uncertainties are usually spatially distributed over the region of the structures and must be modeled as random field and the structures themselves are frequently so complex, the need for an efficient numerical tool to deal the broad class of stochastic structures problems. This may be appropriate handles by probabilistic /stochastic approach. The probabilistic analysis used to incorporate and handle the random system properties yields more accurate prediction of system behavior in terms of mean and COV of thermally induced buckling load of elastically supported laminated composite plates and will results in superior design. Therefore, for accurate prediction of overall behavior of overall system behavior of structures made of composite plate supported on elastic foundation in the presence of randomness in both of the material properties and foundation parameters should be considered.

For reliable and specific design for sensitive application, it is important for the designer to have accurate understanding and knowledge of structural response, other wise the predicted response may differ significantly to actual response leads the structure unsafe. Considering the above aspects, to enhance accuracy in the response evaluation in terms of dimensional mean and COV of buckling load, favors a probabilistic analysis for laminated composite by modeling their system properties as random variables.

Considerable researches based on deterministic analysis have been done on the hygrothermal buckling investigations of composite plates using classical theory of plates, first-order shear deformation theory, or higher order shear deformation theory subjected to uniform or nonuniform moisture and temperature distribution with temperature- and moisture-independent material properties; notably among them are Whitney and Ashton,1 Flaggs et al.,2 Lee and Yen,3 Ram and Sinha,4 Shen,5 Patel et al.,6 Chen and Chen,7 Shen,8 Thankam Sita et al.,9 Shuriyat,10 Pandey et al.11,12 All the above-mentioned literatures are based on the assumptions of complete determinacy of structural parameters, In the deterministic analysis, mean value of system parameters are considered and random variation in the material properties are neglected which gives only mean response and unaccounted the deviation caused by inherent random system properties. A limited literature is available on the analysis of initial and post buckling analysis of the structures with random system properties. In this direction, Nakagiri et al.13 studied all edges simply supported of a laminate with stochastic finite element method (SFEM) taking fiber orientation, layer thickness, and number of layers as random variables. Englested and Reddy14 contributed metal matrix composites based on probabilistic micromechanics nonlinear analysis. Singh et al.15 studied the buckling of composite cylindrical panels with uncertain material properties using probabilistic approach based on HSDT. Effect of random system properties on initial buckling of composite plates resting on elastic foundation using SFEM is studied by Lal et al.16 Post buckling of laminated composite plate on elastic foundation with random system properties based on HSDT in conjunction with FOPT is studied by Singh et al.17 Chen et al.18 outlined the probabilistic method to evaluate the effects of uncertainties in geometric and material properties. Hygrothermal effects on the buckling of laminated composite plates with random geometric and temperature independent material properties are investigated by Singh and Verma.19 Zhang and Ellinwood20 analyzed the effect of material properties on the elastic stability of structural members and frames using stochastic finite element method. They used mean centered first-order perturbation technique (FOPT) using FEM to evaluate the buckling load. Onkar et al.21 used a generalized layerwise stochastic finite element formulation for the buckling analysis of homogeneous and laminated plates with random material properties using FOPT in conjunction with HSDT.

However, no work dealing with hygrothermal buckling analysis of the laminated composite plate resting on elastic foundations with random system properties having temperature and moisture independent and dependent material properties is reported in the literature to the best of the authors’ knowledge.

The present study investigates the hygrothermally induced dimensional mean and COV (=Standard deviation/dimensional mean) of initial buckling load analysis of elastically supported laminated composite plate in the presence of small random variation in system properties, considering transverse shear strain and using higher order shear deformation theory (HSDT). A computationally efficient C 0 continuous finite element method combined with FOPT is employed to determine the second-order statistics (mean and standard deviation) of the hygrothermally induced buckling load of laminated composite plates supported with two parameter Pasternak foundation subjected to uniform hygrothermal loadings with and without temperature- and moisture-dependent material properties with respect to random system properties. The effect of plate parameters (plate thickness ratio, plate aspect ratios, lamination layers, and scheme), moisture concentration and temperature rise, foundation parameters, and support conditions with random system properties are examined.

sec.title: Formulation
sec.p:
A composite plate with arbitrary lamination is considered with the co-ordinates X, Y along the in-plane directions, and Z along the thickness direction as shown in Figure 1. The in-plane displacements u¯v¯ and the transverse displacements w¯ along x, y, and z directions for the k-th layer are assumed as:22,23 (1)u¯=(x,y,z,t)=u(x,y,z,t)+zΨx(x,y,t)+z2βx(x,y,z,t)+z3θx(x,y,z,t)v¯=v(x,y,z,t)+v(x,y,z,t)+zΨy(x,y,t)+z2βy(x,y,z,t)+z3θy(x,y,z,t)w¯(x,y,z,t)=w(x,y,t) where, u, v,, w are the displacements of a generic point (mid) on the reference surface; Ψx, Ψy are the rotations of normal to the reference surface about the y- and x-axes, respectively; βx, βy, θx, θy are the higher order in Taylor series expansions, defined at the reference surface. The thickness coordinate Z of the top and bottom surfaces of any k-th layer are denoted by Z(k − 1) and Z(k) respectively. The fiber of the k-th layer is oriented with angle θk to the x-axes. Figure 1.
Geometry of laminated composite plate resting on elastic foundation.

sec.title: Displacement field model
sec.p: The displacement field model given in Equation (1), after incorporating zero transverse shear stress conditions at the top and the bottom of the plate, requires C1 continuous element approximation in the in-plane displacement field. In order to avoid the usual difficulties associated with the choice of C1 continuous element, the displacement field model has been slightly modified to make the suitability of C 0 continuous element as C 0 continuity permits easy isoparametric finite element formulation and can be applied for nonrectangular geometries as well. In modified form, the derivatives of out-of-plane displacement are themselves considered as separate degree of freedom (DOFs). Thus five DOFs with C1 continuity are transformed into seven DOFs due to conformity with the HSDT. However, the literature Reddy22 demonstrates that without enforcing these constraints, the accurate results can be obtained in order to satisfy the constraints. In this process, the artificial constraints are imposed which should be enforced variationally. The modified displacement field along the x, y, and z directions for an arbitrary composite laminated plate is now written as:24,25 (2)u¯=u+f1(z)Ψx+f2(z)θx;v¯=v+f1(z)Ψy+f2(z)θy;w¯=w; where u, v, and w are corresponding displacements of a point on the mid plane. Ψx and Ψyare the rotations of normal to the mid plane about the y- and x-axes, respectively, with θx=w,x and θy=w,x are slopes along x- and y-axes, respectively. The function f1(z) and f2(z) can be written as: f1(z)=C1z-C2z3;f2(z)=-C4z3 with C1=1,C2=C4=4h2/3
The displacement vector for the modified C 0 continuous models is expressed as: (3){Λ}=[uvwθyθxΨyΨx]T where, comma (,) denotes partial differential.

sec.title: Strain–Displacement relations
sec.p: The strain–displacement relations are obtained by using small deformation theory. The strains corresponding to the displacement field as given in Equation (2) are expressed as:25 (4)ɛxx=ɛ1=u¯,x=ɛ10+z(k10+z2k12)ɛyy=ɛ2=v¯,x=ɛ20+z(k20+z2k22)γxy=ɛ6=u¯,y+v¯,x=ɛ60+z(k60+z2k62)γyz=ɛ4=v¯,z+w¯,y=ɛ40+z2k42γxz=ɛ5=u¯,z+w¯,x=ɛ50+z2k52 where, (5)ɛ10=u,x, k10=Ψx,x, k12=-4/3h2(Ψx,x+w,x2)ɛ20=v,x, k20=Ψy,y, k22=-4/3h2(Ψy,y+w,y2)ɛ60=u,y+v,x, k60=Ψx,y+Ψy,x, k62=-4/3h2 (Ψx,y+Ψy,x+2w,xy)ɛ40=Ψy+w,y, k42=-4/h2(Ψx+w,y)ɛ50=Ψx+w,x, k52=-4/h2(Ψx+w,x)
The mid plane strain vector {ɛ¯} for the above model is expressed as (6){ɛ¯l}=(ɛ10ɛ20ɛ60k10k20k60k12k22k62ɛ40ɛ50k42k52)T

sec.title: Stress–Strain relation
sec.p: The constitutive law of hygrothermal elasticity for the materials under consideration relates the stresses with strains in a plane stress state for the k-th lamina oriented as an arbitrary angle with respect to the reference axis for an orthotropic layer is given by:26–28 (7){σ}k=[Q¯]k{ɛ}kor{σxσyσxyσyzσxz}k=[Q¯11Q¯12Q¯1600Q¯12Q¯22Q¯2600Q¯16Q¯26Q¯6600000Q¯44Q¯45000Q¯45Q¯55]k{ɛx-αxΔT-βxΔCɛy-αyΔT-βyyΔCɛxy-αxyΔT-βyΔCɛyzɛzx}k where {Q¯}k, {σ}k, and {ɛ}k are transformed stiffness matrix, stress, and strain vectors of the k-th lamina, respectively with (αx, αy, αxy), and (βxx, βyy, βxy) being the thermal expansion and hygroscopic contraction coefficients along x, y, z, directions, respectively which can be obtained from the thermal and hygroscopic coefficients in the longitudinal (αl) and transverse (αt) directions of the fibers using transformation matrix. ΔT and ΔC are the uniform temperature and moisture concentration field distribution.

Substituting Equation (4) into Equation (6) and integrating through thickness gives a relationship between stress resultants and mid-plane strain which are:26 (8a){NiMiPi}=[AijBijEijBijDijFijEijFijHij]{ɛj0kj0kj2}-{NiHTMiHTPiHT}; (i,j=1,2,6) (8b){Q2Q1}=[A4jD4jA5jD5j]{ɛj0kj2};{R2R1}=[D4jF4jD5jF5j] {ɛj0kj2} (j=4,5) Where the stress resultants per unit length {Ni}=[NixNiyNixy]T, {Mi}=[MixMiyMixy]T, and {Pi}=[PixPiyPixy]Tare expressed in terms of mid plane strains and curvatures.27–29

The hygrothermal stress and moments resultants per unit length due to uniform temperature and moisture change are calculated and the equivalent hygrothermal loads are defined as:3 (9)NiHT=[N]T+[N]C, MiHT=[M]T+[M]C, PiHT=[P]T+[P]C For the hygrothermally induced buckling it is assumed that the plate is subjected to uniform temperature and moisture rise (UT) through the plate thickness and is expressed as: (10)T(X,Y,Z)=[T0+C0]

sec.title: Strain energy of the plate
sec.p: The strain energy (Π1) of the laminated composite plates can be expressed as: (11a)Π1=12∫A[(Ni+Mi+Pi)ɛxx+(Ni+Mi+Pi)ɛyy +(Ni+Mi+Pi)γxy+Q¯1γxz+Q¯2γyz]dxdy

sec.title: Strain energy due to elastic foundation
sec.p: In the present analysis, the plate is supported by foundation excluding any separation during process of deformation as shown in Figure 1. At the equilibrium condition, the load displacement relationship between the plate and supporting foundation fallows by two parameters Pasternak model as P=K1w-K2∇2w with ∇2=∂,x2+∂,y2 where P, K1, K2, and w are the foundation reaction per unit area, normal (spring) and shear stiffness of foundation, transverse displacement, and Laplace differential operator, respectively. In the Winkler foundation model, the parameter K2 given in above expression is assumed as zero.
The strain energy (Π2) due to elastic foundation having shear deformable layers can be written as16: (11b)Π2=12∫A{K1w2+K2[(w,x)2+(w,y)2]}dA==12∫A{ww,xw,y}T[K1000K2000K2]{ww,xw,y}dA

sec.title: Potential energy due to hygrothermal stresses
sec.p: Due to uniform change in temperature and moisture, pre-buckling stresses, i.e., in plane hygrothermal compressive stress resultants in the plate are generated. These resultants in-plane buckling stress are the reason for buckling. The potential energy (Π2) due to the in-plane hygrothermal stress resultants is expressed as: (12)Π3=12∫A[NxTH(w,x)2+NyTH(w,y)2+2NxyTH(w,x)(w,y)]dA=12∫A{w,xw,y}T[NxTHNxyTHNxyTHNyTH]{w,xw,y}dA where, NxTH NyTH, and NxyTH are in-plane hygrothermal compressive stress resultants per unit length along x, y and x-y directions, respectively.

sec.title: Strain energy of the plate element
sec.p: In the present study, a C 0 nine-noded isoparametric finite element with 7 DOFs per node is employed. For this type of element, the displacement vector and the element geometry are expressed as: (13){Λ}=∑i=1NNϕi{Λ}i; x=∑i=1NNϕixi; and y=∑i=1NNϕiyi where ϕi is the interpolation function for the i-th node, {Λ}i is the vector of unknown displacements for the i-th node, NN is the number of nodes per element, and xi and yi are Cartesian Coordinate of the i-th node.

The linear mid plane strain vector as given in Equation (6) can be expressed in terms of mid-plane displacement field and then energy is computed for each element and then summed over all the elements to get the total potential energy of the system. Following this and using Equation (13), Equation (11a) can be written as: (14)Π1=∑e=1NEΠ1(e) where, NE is the number of elements and Π1(e) is the elemental total potential energy which can be expressed as: (15)Π1=∑e=1NE[12{Λ(e)}T[K(e)]{Λ}(e)-{Λ(e)}T[FHT(e)]]=12{q}T[K]{q}-{q}T[FHT] with [K]=[Kb]+[Ks] where global buckling stiffness matrix [Kg], shear stiffness matrix [Ks], global displacement vector {q}, and hygrothermal load vector [FHT] are defined in the Appendix.

sec.title: Foundation analysis
Hygrothermal buckling analysis
sec.p: Adopting Gauss quadrature integration numerical rule, the global plate stiffness matrix, foundation and geometric stiffness matrix respectively can be obtained by transforming expression in x, y coordinate system to natural coordinate system ξ, η.

sec.title: Governing equation
sec.p: The governing equation for hygrothermal buckling analysis of laminated composite plate can be derived using variational principle,30 which is generalization of the principle of virtual displacement. For the pre-buckling analysis, the first variation of total potential energy Π = (Π1 + Π2 + Π3) must be zero. Following these ones obtain by using Equations (15), (16), and (17): (18)[K]{q}=[FT] For the critical buckling state corresponding to the neutral equilibrium condition, the second variation of total potential energy (Π) must be zero. Following this conditions, ones obtain as standard eigenvalue problem: (19)|[K]+λ[Kg]|=0

The pre-buckling equations is solved to compute the stress state in the plate subjected a hygrothermal loads corresponding to unit temperature and moisture rise, neglecting the geometric stiffness matrix. Based on this stress state, the geometric stiffness matrix is constructed. To compute the critical temperature and moisture at which bucking occurs, Equation (20) is solved.

The stiffness matrix [K] and geometric stiffness matrix [Kg] are random in nature, being dependent on the system geometric and hygrothermo-elastic properties. Therefore the eigenvalues and eigenvectors also become random. In deterministic environment, the solution of Equation (20) can be obtained using conventional eigenvalue method. However, in random environment, it is not possible to obtain the solution using above numerical method. For this, further analysis is required to obtain the complete solution of Equation (20). For this purpose, novel probabilistic procedure obtained by computationally efficient C 0 finite FEM combined with FOPT, i.e., SFEM developed by the present authors16 for plate with thermal loadings are extended to compute the second-order statistics (mean and coefficient of variance (COV)) of hygrothermally induced buckling load.

sec.title: Solutions – Perturbation technique
sec.p: In the present analysis, basic input random variables such as Young’s modulus, shear modulus, thermal expansion coefficient and hygroscopic contraction coefficient, and foundation parameters are treated as basic input random variables.

In general, without any loss of generality any arbitrary random variable can be represented as the sum of its mean and zero mean random part, denoted by superscripts ‘d’ and ‘r’, respectively:25 (21)K=Kd+Kr, Kg=Kgd+Kgr, λi=λid+λir, qi=qid+qir where i = 1, 2,…, p. The parameter p indicates the size of eigen problem.

By substituting Equation (21) in Equation (20) and expanding the random parts in Taylor’s series keeping the first-order terms and neglecting the second and higher order terms since the first-order approximation is sufficient to yield results with desired accuracy having low variability as the case of the sensitive applications,31 collecting same order of the magnitude term, one obtains as:29,32
Zeroth-order perturbation equation: (22)[Kd]{qid}=λid[Kg]{qid}
First-order perturbation equation: (23)[Kd]{qir}+[Kr]{qid}=λid[Kgr]{qid}+λid[Kgd]{qir} +λir[Kgd]{qid}

Equation (22) is the deterministic equation relating to the mean eigenvalues and corresponding mean eigenvectors, which can be determined by conventional eigensolution procedure. Equation (23) is the random equation, defining the stochastic nature of the hygrothermal induced buckling which cannot be solved using conventional method. For this a further analysis is required.

According to the orthogonality properties, the normalized eigenvectors meet the following conditions:29 (24){qid}T[Kgd]{qid}=δij (25){qid}T[Kd]{qid}=δijλid,(i,j)=1,2,…,p where δij is the Kronecker delta.

The eigenvectors, which meet orthogonality conditions33,34 after being properly normalized, form a complete orthonormal set and any vector in the space can be expressed as their linear combination of these eigenvectors. Hence, the i-th random part of the eigenvectors can be expressed as: (26){qir}=∑j=1pCijr{qid},i≠j,Ciir=0,i=1,2,…,p where Cijr’s are small random coefficients to be determined.
Substituting Equation (28) into Equation (26), one obtains: (29){qir}=∑j=1p{qid}{qjd}T[Kr]{qid}-λid{qjd}T[Kgr]{qid}λid-λjd,i≠j

For the present case λ, {q}, [K], and [Kg] are random because of random geometric and material properties. Let b1R, b2R, b3R,…, bqR denote random variables (system properties). The random variables (RVs) can be expressed as: (30)bjR=bjd+bjr

The FEM in conjunction with the FOPT has been found to be accurate and efficient.31,33 According to this method, the random variables are expressed by Taylor’s series expansion. The expression only up to the first-order terms and neglecting the second- and higher order terms are given as: (31)λir=∑j=1pλjdhjr;{qir}=∑j=1p{qjd}hjr;[Kr]=∑j=1p[Kjd]hjr;[Kgr]=∑j=1p[Kjd]hjr where j denotes the partial differentiation with respect to bj.
On substitution of Equation (31) into Equation (27), one obtains as: (32)λjd={qid}T[Kjd]{qid}-λid{qid}T[Kjd]{qid}

The variance of the eigenvalues can now be expressed as:29,35 (33)Var(λi)=∑j=1q∑k=1qλi,jdλi,kdCov(bjr,bkr) where Cov(bjr,bkr) is the covariance between bjr and bkr. The standard deviation (SD) is obtained by the square root of the variance. As revealed by the expression, the hygrothermally induced buckling load dispersion (SD) of the laminated composite plate exhibit linear variation with all random input variables.

sec.title: Numerical results and discussion
sec.p: The stochastic finite element analysis (SFEM), outlined in the previous subsection has been used to obtain the second-order statistics (expected (dimensional) mean and COV) of hygrothermally induced buckling load of laminated composite plate considering different random system parameters as stated earlier by computer program developed in MATLAB 9.0.0 [R2009a] environment. Being a linear nature of variation as seen and posing through the origin the results are only presented by SD/Mean known as coefficient of correlation (COC) equal to 0.1.35 However, the obtained results reveal that the stochastic approach would be valid up to COC equal to 0.20.31 Moreover, the presented results would be sufficient to extrapolate the results for other coefficient of variation value keeping in mind the limitation of FOPT.31 The thickness of all the lamina is assumed to be constant for sake of simplicity and of same material without varying individual property of materials used. The probabilistic results obtained by present SFEM have been compared with independent MCS and those available in the literatures. For the present study a nine nodded serendipity element, with 63 degree of freedom (DOFs) per element modified form HSDT-based C 0 finite element model has been used for discretizing the laminate. Based on convergence, an (4 × 4) mesh has been used throughout for evaluation of the results. The results have been computed by employing the full (3 × 3) integration rule for bending stiffness matrices, hygrothermal load vector and the geometric stiffness matrices and the reduced (2 × 2) integration rule for computing the shear stiffness matrices to avoid shear locking in the thin plates. It is noted that in the present analysis, mean centered FOPT has been used to compute the numerical results, keeping in mind the complicity and difficulty of using higher order perturbation at cost of very little improvement of results.
The boundary conditions for the plate are expressed as
All edges simply supported (SSSS (S1)): u=w=θy=Ψy=0,atx=0,a; v=w=θx=Ψx=0aty=0,b;
All edges simply supported (SSSS (S2)): v=w=θy=Ψy=0,atx=0,a; u=w=θx=Ψx=0aty=0,b;
All edges clamped (CCCC): u=v=w=Ψx=Ψy=θx=θy=0,atx=0,a andy=0,b;
Two opposite edge clamped and other two simply supported (CSCS): u=v=w=Ψx=Ψy=θx=θy=0,atx=0, and y=0;u=w=θy=Ψy=0,atx=a;v=w=θx=Ψx=0,aty=b
It is noted that the value of expected mean hygrothermal buckling load is taken dimensional form with the multiplication of 108 in the whole table and graphs unless otherwise stated.

However, for the foundation analysis, the following dimensionless parameters are used for computation of results as: k1=K1b4/E22h3andk2=K2b2/E22h3 where, k1 and k2 are Winkler (spring) and shear foundation parameters, respectively. In the present analysis, two parameters Pasternak foundation consisting of Winkler (k1 = 100, k2 = 0) and Pasternak (k1 = 100, k2 = 10) stiffness parameters have been used.

The plate geometry used is characterized by aspect ratios (a/b) = 1 and 2, side to thickness ratios (b/h) = 30, 40, 50, 60, 80, and 100. The mean values of coefficients of hygroscopic expansion, coefficients of thermal expansion, elastic foundations, and material constants are used for computation. We now consider a second steps as the elastic constants, thermal expansion coefficients and coefficients of hygroscopic expansion of each layers are assumed to be linear function of temperature and moisture. The only exception is the Poisson’s ratio, which can reasonably be assumed as constant due to weakly dependency on temperature change. For the ratio of the SD to the mean of material and geometric properties varying from 0 to 20% with b/h = 10, 20, 30, 40 and 50 have been considered. The hygrothermo-elastic material properties such as E11, E22, G12, G13, G23, α1, α2, β2, and h are modeled as basic random variables (RVs). The input random variables bi is related as b1 = E11, b2 = E22, b3 = G12, b4 = G13, b5 = G23, b6 = α1, b7 = α2, b8 = β2, b9 = k1, and b10 = k2. For the temperature and moisture dependent material properties (TD) The relation among Elastic constants are given as: E11=E10(1+E111T1+E111C1), E22=E20(1+E211T1+E211C1)G12=G120(1+G121T1+G121C1), G13=G130(1+G131T1+G131C1)G23=G230(1+G231T1+G231C1), α1=α10(1+α11T1),α2=α20(1+α21T1),β1=β10(1+β11C1), β2=β20(1+β21C2) where, temperature- and moisture-dependent material properties are defined as: E111=-0.5×10-3E221=G121=G131=G231=-0.2×10-3α11=α21=0.5×10-3β1=β1=0.5×10-3

All layers are of equal thickness for the temperature-independent material properties (TID) E11,E21,G121,G131,G231,α11, α21m,β11, and β21 quantities are taken equal to zero. The material property for the analysis of hygrothermal buckling analysis is taken from Tables 1 and 2 while Tables 3–5 for validation purposes and Tables 6–15 for generation of the results for various combinations. Table 1.
Elastic moduli of graphite/epoxy lamina at different moisture concentrations. G130 = G120, G230 = 05 G120, v12 = 0.3, β10 = 0, β20 = 0.44
Elastic moduli (GPa) Moisture concentration C (%)
0.00 0.25 0.50 0.75 1.0 1.25 1.50
E10 130 130 130 130 130 130 130
E20 9.5 9.25 9.0 8.75 8.5 8.5 8.5

sec.title: Validation study for expected mean hygrothermally induced post buckling load
sec.p:
To make certain the accuracy of the present deterministic finite element method three test examples (Tables 3 and 4 and Figure 2) have been analyzed for expected mean hygrothemally induced buckling load response of laminated composite plates supported with and without elastic foundation. Figure 2.
Validation study of dimensionless mean post buckling temperature of simply supported (S1) biaxial compressed square laminated (45°/−45°)2]T composite plate resting on two-parameter Pasternak elastic foundation with TID material properties with a/h = 10.

Tables 3 and 4 shows the comparison of effect of temperature and moisture on nondimensionalized critical load Ncrt = (Ncr/Ncr0)at T = 300K and C = 0, of cross-ply [(0°/90°)4] square simply supported (S2) biaxial compressed laminates with a/h = 5 under uniform moisture and temperature distribution. It is noticed that the present HSDT-based computationally efficient C0 FEM for expected mean deterministic buckling load results are in good agreement and validated with the results of Patel et al.6 employed various theories with C1 FEM.

Figure 2 shows the comparison of post buckling temperature results of simply supported (S1) square biaxial compressed angle-ply [(45°/−45°)2]T, laminated square biaxial compressed composite plate resting on two parameter Pasternak elastic foundation subjected to TID material properties having a/h = 10. It is observed that present results obtained by C0 FEM based on HSDT for post buckling temperature of plate supported with Pasternak elastic foundation are in good agreement with the available literature of Pandey et al.11 based on Chebishev polynomial-based analytical results with HSDT.

sec.title: Validation study for random hygrothermally induced buckling load
sec.p: Due to unavailability of results for random hygrothermally induced buckling load for laminated composite plate resting on elastic foundation, the present SFEM results have been compared with the results obtained by independent MCS.

The present results of random hygrothermally induced buckling load of laminated composite plate resting on Winkler (k1 = 100, k2 = 0) elastic foundation obtained from present perturbation approach have been compared with independent MCS approach. Figure 3 plots the coefficient of variation (COV = SD/mean) of the hygrothermally induced buckling load versus the COV of the random material constant for angle-ply antisymmetric [(±45°)2]T square SSSS (S2) supported laminated composite plate resting on Winkler elastic foundation subjected to temperature and moisture TID and TD material properties with b/h = 20 and ΔT = 325 K, ΔC = 1% varying from 0 to 10%.35 It is assumed that one of the material property (i.e., E22) changes at a time keeping other as a deterministic with their mean value. The present FOPT result based on Taylor series based technique are compared with the results obtained by independent MCS approach. For the MCS approach, the samples of material property are generated using MATLAB to fit the desired mean and SD. These samples used in response are solved repeatedly, adopting conventional eigenvalue procedure, to generate a sample of the hygrothermal buckling load. The number of samples used for MCS approach is 10,000 based on satisfactory convergence of the results. The normal distribution has been assumed for random number generations in MCS. However, the present perturbation approach used in the study does not put any limitation as regard to probability distribution of the system property. This is an advantage over the MCS. From the figure it is clear that, close correlation is achieved between two results. Figure 3.
Validation study of present FOPT results with independent MCS approach for hygrothermally induced buckling load of simply supported (S2) biaxial compressed angle-ply (45°/−45°)2]T laminated square plate resting on Winkler (k1 = 100, k2 = 0) elastic foundation subjected to TID and TD material properties with a/h = 20 and ΔT = 325 K, ΔC = 1%.

Table 5 shows the effects of the variation of individual random system property, bi, {(i = 1 to 10) = 0.10} on the dimensionlized expected mean and COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load of angle-ply [(45°/−45°)2]T square biaxial compressed laminated composite plates resting on elastic foundations subjected to temperature and moisture TID and TD material properties with a/h = 20 and ΔT = 325 K, ΔC = 1.25%. The mean hygrothermally induced buckling load (λcr × 108 N/m) are given in brackets. It is observed that hygrothermally induced buckling load of laminated plate is most sensitive to random change in COV of E11, E22, β22, and k2 compared to all other random input variables in case plate resting on Winkler and Pasternak foundations. Tight control of these parameters is therefore required for high reliability of composite plates. It is also observed that the expected mean thygrothermally induced buckling load is higher in TID case of plate resting on Pasternak foundation. It is because the foundation parameters makes the stiffness of the plate higher.

The effects of thickness ratios (b/h), support conditions (namely, SSSS (S2) and CCCC) and random input variables bi, [{(i = 1 to 8), (6, 7), (8) and (9, 10)} = 0.10] on the dimensionalized expected mean and COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load of angle-ply [±45°]2T square biaxial compressed laminated composite plate resting on two parameter Pasternak elastic foundation subjected to temperature and moisture independent TID and TD material properties with ΔT = 325, ΔC = 1.25% is shown in Tables 6 and 7. It is observed that the expected mean hygrothermally induced buckling load decreases and corresponding COV increases with random change in all hygrothermal material properties of simply supported and clamped supported plate when thickness ratio increases subjected to both TID and TD material properties. For the clamped supported plate the COV decreases while expected mean increases drastically; however, it is further decreased when thickness ratio increases for both TID and TD case. It is due to the increased effect of boundary constraints which significantly increases the stiffness of the plate. It is also seen that for the plate resting on Pasternak foundation the expected mean values are higher and coefficient of variation is decreased for various input variable combinations for both simple support and clamped support boundary conditions compared with Winkler Foundations. Table 7.

Tables 8 and 9 shows the effects of aspect ratios (a/b), random input variables bi, [{(i = 1 to 8), (6, 7), (8) and (9, 10)} = 0.10] and support conditions (SSSS (S2) and CCCC) on the dimensionlized expected mean and coefficient of variation of hygrothermally induced buckling of [±45°]2T angle-ply biaxial compressed laminated composite plates resting on two parameter Pasternak elastic foundations subjected to temperature and moisture independent TID and TD system parameters with a/h = 50 and ΔT = 325 K, ΔC = 1.25%. It is seen that expected mean is more and corresponding COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load is less for square simply supported and clamped plate resting on two parameters Pasternak elastic foundation subjected to TID and TD material properties with random change in all hygrothermal material properties. However, COV of buckling load decreases for random change in foundation parameters. It can be observed that the expected mean values are increased and coefficient of variation is decreased compared to Winkler support; however, combined effect of input variables has significant effects on coefficient of variation. The effects of various support conditions (SSSS (S1), (S2), CCCC, and CSCS) and random input variables bi,[{(i = 1 to 8), (6, 7), (8) and (9, 10)} = 0.10] on the dimensionalized expected mean and COV of hygrothermally induced buckling of square angle-ply [(±45°)2]T laminated square biaxial compressed composite plates subjected to temperature and moisture TID and TD material properties with ΔT = 325 K, ΔC = 0.0125, and a/h = 60 is shown in Tables 10 and 11. It is observed that the expected mean hygrothermally induced buckling load of clamped supported plate is highest while, COV is lowest for both of the TID and TD material properties with Winkler and Pasternak elastic foundation. It is due to the increased effect of boundary constraints which significantly increases the stiffness of the plate as discussed earlier. However, COV of simply supported (S2) plate is highest for both of the TID and TD material properties. It is also observed that plate is more sensitive with combined effect of all random input parameters and random moisture coefficient. Tight control of these combinations of input random parameters is therefore required for high reliability of the plate. Table 10.

Tables 12 and 13 shows the effects of lamina lay-up sequences and random input variables bi, [{(i = 1 to 8), (6, 7), (8) and (9, 10)} = 0.10] on the dimensionalized expected mean and COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load of simply supported (S2) laminated square composite biaxial compressed plates resting on two parameter Pasternak elastic foundation subjected to temperature and moisture TID and TD material properties with ΔT = 325 K, ΔC = 0.0125, and a/h = 10. It is noticed that lamina lay-up does not affect much in expected mean and COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load for angle-ply symmetric and antisymmetric. However, when the lay-up cross ply lamination is changed to symmetric and antisymmetric the effects are higher for expected mean values for both TID and TD conditions whereas COV is not of significance in all combinations. It is expected that plate supported with Pasternak elastic foundation shows higher expected mean and lower COV than plate with Winkler elastic foundation with TID and TD material properties. The expected mean are higher and corresponding COV are lower when the lay-up is changed from angle-ply to cross-ply in both TID and TD case. Table 12.

The effects of Environmental conditions and random input variables bi, [{(i = 1 to 8), (6, 7), (8) and (9, 10)} = 0.10] on the dimensionalized expected mean and COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load of angle-ply [(45°/−45°)2]T laminated simply supported square composite plates resting on two parameter Pasternak elastic foundation subjected to temperature and moisture TID and TD material properties with uniform constant temperature, a/h = 100 is shown in Tables 14 and 15. It is seen that change in environmental conditions increase the expected mean values and corresponding COV in both TID and TD case. It is because of environmental condition decreases the strength and stiffness of the plate. However, COV is higher for combined random variables and of significance compared to all different parameters. It is observed that COV of buckling load with all random input variables acting simultaneously or separately for the plate with TD material properties is higher than TID material properties while expected mean shows opposite effect. It is because of temperature increments makes the stiffness of the plate lowers. It is also observed that plate is more sensitive to random change in all material properties and foundation parameters. Table 14.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
A C0 FEM in conjunction with FOPT is employed to compute the expected mean and COV of the hygrothermally induced buckling load of elastically supported laminated composite plate with TID and TD properties, random change in all input random system variables. Assumptions are made for uniform distribution of temperature and moisture over entire surface and through the thickness of laminated composite plate. The following main conclusions can be drawn from the limited investigation.
The FOPT gives acceptable results for the range of COV (SD/mean) taken in the study. It is observed that the effect of the coefficient of variation for E11, E22, β2, and k2 are more significant as compared to all other random input variables. Tight control of these parameters is therefore required for high reliability of the plate.
The characteristics of hygrothermally induced buckling load of laminated composite plate is significantly influenced by various support conditions, plate thickness ratios, aspect ratios, elastic foundations, temperature and moisture changes. The mean hygrothermal buckling load and coefficient of variation of plate is lower than when the plate is subjected to temperature independent hygrothermo-material properties.
The clamp supported plate buckle at slightly higher temperature and moisture compared to other supports. Hygrothermally induced buckling is less dominant in plate made of temperature and moisture independent material properties. It is also noticed that plate with Pasternak foundation support shows the higher expected mean and corresponding lower COV compared to Winkler foundation.
The COV of hygrothermally induced buckling load due to variation in material properties is dependent on thickness ratios and boundary conditions of the laminate. The components made of laminated composite materials, when used for hygrothermal sensitive application may buckle well before the prescribed period of use may not be reliable, durable, economical, and safe.
